2. Create resources (use different fs type for storage related resource : ext4,ext3,xfs)

        b. fio-rc : static provisioning 4 pods.
        c. fio-rc: dynamic provisioning 4 pods.
        e. create lcv from above volumes's snapshot (step c) and create fio rc for them.  After upgrade create snapshot of this lcv.
        f. fio-rc-mirror : static provisioning 4 pods.
        g. fio-rc-mirror: dynamic provisioning 4 pods.
        h. create lcv from above volumes's snapshot (step g) [Create fio rc for these lcv after upgrade]
        i. nfs-client-rc
        j. iSCSI-rc (Windows target details given in desription.)
        k. Deployments of fio.
        l. Statefulset with endpoint prefix in different namespace. 
        m. Statefulset fio with multiple volumes.
        n. Deployment nginx
        o. Create 4 fio rc pod mirror count 1, use fio-verify image. [Verify data after upgrade. Then increase the mirror count and verify data on new plexes.]
        p. Create 4 fio rc pod with mirror count 3, use fio-vrify image [ verify data after upgrade]
        q. KVM pods. (one pod per node.)

1) Create mirrored volumes. Attach them to a node.

Steps :-
1) Launch 8 pair of server-client using helm chart or deployment

1) Create a local, remote and mirrored volume. Run fio on the volumes with --size=size1. Calculate cksum of the volumes across all plexes (cksum1). 
2) Create snapshot of the volumes. 
3) Store the values of FBM and L1 usage of the node where the snapshot exists. (val1)
4) Run more IOs on the volumes with different pattern and --size=size2. size2 should be greater than size1. Calculate cksum of the volumes across all plexes (cksum2). 
5) cksum2 should not be equal to cksum1. 
6) Calculate the values of FBM and L1 usage on the node where the snapshot exists (val2). val2 should be greater than val1.
7) Detach the volumes. Restore the data from snapshot to the volumes. Attach the volumes. 
8) Allow all plexes to complete resync. 
9) Calculate cksum of the volumes across all plexes (cksum3). 
10) cksum3 should match with cksum1
11) Calculate the values of FBM and L1 usage on the node where the snapshot exists. (val3)
12) val1 should match with val3
13) Add a plex to all the volumes. Allow the plexes to resync.
14) After resync completes, calculate cksum across all plexes (cksum4)
15) cksum4 should match with cksum3

Scenario: Restoring data on LCV from it's snapshot
Description:
1) Create local, remote and mirrored volumes. Run IOs on the volumes. Calculate cksum of the volumes (cksum1). 
2) Create snapshot of the volumes (snap1). 
3) Create LCVs out of the snapshot (lcv1). Attach it. Calculate cksum (cksum2). cksum2 should match cksum1. 
4) Calculate the FBM and L1 usage on the nodes where the snapshot exists. (val1)
5) Run IOs on the LCV (lcv1) with different pattern. Calculate cksum of LCV (cksum3). cksum3 should not match cksum2.
6) Create snapshot out of LCV (snap2). Create LCV (lcv2) out of the snapshot (snap2). Attach the LCV. Calculate cksum of the LCV (cksum4). cksum4 should match with cksum3.
7) Create snapshot out of lcv2 (snap3).
8) Calculate the FBM and L1 usage on the nodes where the snapshot exists. (val2)
9) Run IOs on the LCV (lcv2) with different pattern. Calculate cksum of LCV (cksum5). cksum5 should not match cksum4.
10) Detach the LCV (lcv2). Restore data on lcv2 using the snapshot snap3. Attach the lcv2. Calculate cksum of lcv2 (cksum6). cksum6 should match with cksum4.
11) Calculate the FBM and L1 usage on the nodes where the snapshot exists. (val3)
12) val3 should match with val2.
13) Detach and delete lcv2 and snap3. Calculate cksum again on lcv1 (cksum7). cksum7 should match with cksum3.
14) Detach lcv1. Restore data on lcv1 using snap2. Attach lcv1 again. 
15) Calculate cksum again on lcv1 (cksum8). cksum8 should match with cksum3.
16) Calculate the FBM and L1 usage on the nodes where the snapshot exists. (val4)
17) val4 should match with val2

1) Create fio pods with local, remote and mirrored volumes using dynamic PVCs across a few namespaces. Use fsTypes ext3, ext4 and xfs.
2) Create few PVCs & volumes manually (local, remote & mirrored). Attach them. Create file systems (ext3, ext4 and xfs). Mount the volumes. 
3) Allow the pods to run for few mins.
4) Run fio manually on the manually created volumes (write to file inside the mounted directory). Add some other files and directories also in the mounted directory. Calculate checksum of some of the files (cksum1). Detach some manually created volumes. Don't detach some. 
5) Create Volume Replicator Config in each namespace and list the PVC names to be backedup in each namespace. Mention the storage classes that would be used in DRC for some PVCs. Don't mention it for some PVCs.
6) PVCs with the same name should be created on the DRC using the given storage classes. If the storage class isn't mentioned or doesn't exist on DRC, default storage class will be used.
7) Replicator will create a nfs server on the DRC which will attach the volumes.
8) Replicator will create a kubernetes cronjob on the PC. 
9) Kubernetes cronjob will create a replication job periodically based on the given schedule.
10) The replication job will create snapshot out of those PVCs and LCVs out of snapshots and create rsync agent pods.
11) Volumes on DRC are mounted as NFS volume to rsync agent pod. 
12) These rsync agent pods will rsync the data from LCVs to the corresponding volumes on DRC.
13) Wait for replication job to complete.
14) After the replication job is complete, the cronjob will go in Suspended mode.
15) Replicator will now create snapshots of all the volumes on the DRC. Snapshot should be in Available state. If there is any error during replication, snapshot won't be created.
16) After creation of snapshots, the cronjob should resume. 
17) On the DRC side, attach the manually created volumes. Mount them. The files and directories created in step4 should appear. Calculate checksum of the files (cksum2).

Create 8 volumes (mixed of simple, remote and mirrored ones) of different sizes. Attach, do fio write & verify pattern, detach, resize them to different sizes, attach, verify pattern, do fio write-pattern on extended region/offset of resized volume, verify pattern. 
Note :  Here grow the volumes such that following cases are covered : a) Only L1 blocks of LDs increase by few but no of L0s remain same, b) No of L0 blocks of LDs increase but no new SV added c) New SV(s) are added. 
Note : 
LDFS_BLOCK_SIZE = 4K
LDFS_BLOCKS_IN_ONE_L1 = 800
L1_BLOCKS_IN_ONE_L0 = 4K
L0_BLOCKS_IN_ONE_LD = 64
STRIPE_CNT = 4
a)        To add 1 L1 block in LDs of a volume, increase its size max by 12800K,
b)        To add 1 L0 block in LDs of a volume, increase its size by 4(stripe-cnt)* 4K(L1 entries in L0) * 800 (Data-block entries in L1) * 4K (ldfs block size) = 51200M
c)        To add 1 new SV in plex(es) of a volume, increase its size by SV size, i.e. 64 (max L0 blocks in a LD)*51200M = 3276800M

Enable CRIO at node preparation on all nodes. Create cluster and run pods. Verify whether pods are running and networking and storage traffic is working fine.

Enable CRIO on few nodes & let docker remain default runtime on other nodes. Run fio and iperf pods such that resources from both type of nodes are used. Verify storage and network traffic (example : iperf-server on CRIO node and iperf-client on docker node)
With CRIO enabled node, validate qos for fio pods. Use different fstype and qos
With CRIO enabled node, validate qos for iperf pods. Use different qos.
Verify kubectl commands like logs, exec, describe, etc are working fine and showing expected results
Verify dctl event list is working and has entries for containers corresponding to CRIO node
Verify GUI shows all type of stats for CRIO enabled node
Run pods. Reboot the nodes. After the node comes up, the pods should restart and move to running state. Verify that the pods are transferring data.
With CRIO enabled, run "kubectl get nodes -o wide". It should show contianer runtime as CRIO

Enable CRIO. Run pods. Delete pods. Remove the node. Clean-up the system. Disable CRIO. Enable docker (docker will be enabled by default). Run pods. Pods should run without issues. Verify whether they are using docker as runtime. Delete the pods. Remove the node. Clean-up the system. Enable CRIO. Create pods. Verify whether they are using CRIO as runtime. All pods should be running fine and transmitting data
Check CRIO version. The major version should match with kubernetes version.
Enable CRIO on all nodes. Run all pod related e2e automated TCs. Should pass
Enable CRIO on all nodes. Run stress test. Should pass
Enable CRIO on all nodes. Run stress test with link flap. Should pass
Use docker. Run upgrade matrix with CRIO enabled on the nodes getting upgraded. Containers should work fine post upgrade.
Use docker. Run upgrade matrix with CRIO enabled only on few nodes getting upgraded. (mix of docker and CRIO nodes) Containers should work fine post upgrade.
Use CRIO. Run upgrade matrix with docker enabled on the nodes getting upgraded. Containers should work fine post upgrade. Verify docker is being used as runtime
Create 3 nginx pods,Create Cluster Ip service,Check the ClusterIp service is working with default network from the pod domain or not.
Create 3nginx pods and service with cluster ip. Create httperf pod. Check data is going through host-interface or not from client.
Create  Iperf server pod with diamanti network [host-network] and create client pod with management network and see whether data transfer is going or not and bandwidth should be ~9G
Create 3 nginx pods,Creating Headless Service and check the Head-less service is reachable with the default network from the pod domain or not.
Create 3 nginx pods,Create Headless Service and check the Head-Less service is working with host-network from the pod domain or not.
Create  Iperf server pod with diamanti network and create client pod with management network and see whether data transfer is going or not and check the performance.
Run "sudo kata-runtime kata-check" on the node. Shouldn't show any errors
In pod spec, use runtimeClassName as "untrusted". The pods should then run using kata-runtime
In pod spec, use runtimeClassName that hasn't been created. The pods should remain in Pending state

Create cluster with some nodes as CRIO enabled and some with docker runtime. Create RC / Deployments using runtimeClassName as "untrusted". The pods should get scheduled on only those nodes which are CRIO enabled.
Check whether runtimeclass object exists on the cluster.
Validate qos for fio pods. Use different fstype and qos
Validate qos for iperf pods. Use different qos.
Verify kubectl commands like logs, exec, describe, etc are working fine and showing expected results on kata pods
Verify dctl event list is working and has entries for kata containers
Verify GUI shows all type of stats for kata containers
Run pods with kata-runtime. Reboot the nodes. After the node comes up, the pods should restart and move to running state. Verify that the pods are transferring data.
Run all pod related e2e automated TCs with kata-runtime. Should pass. (Sourabh's comment : This may not be true. There will be some tests that may not pass due to perf. gap)
Run stress test with pods using kata-runtime. Should pass. (Sourabh's comment : Suggest starting with less stress and then gradually increase. Remember we have only 1 CPU core per kata vm)
Run stress test with link flap using kata-runtime. Should pass
Create PVC with storage size > limitrange.storage.Max (in  limits)
Run upgrade matrix with CRIO enabled on the nodes getting upgraded. Create new pods / RCs that will use kata-runtime. Containers should work fine and transfer data

Create a cluster with 2 zones.
Update a zone which does not have master node with master-disable:false zone capability. 
The nodes of that zone should be allowed for master election.
Migrate master to the etcd node of updated zone capability.
a.Using dctl cluster configure --master command
b.And by powering off master.
ExpectedBehaviour: Failure for dctl cluster configure command.[Resolved]
Notes:
master-disabled=false --> master can be scheduled
master-disabled=true --> master cannot be scheduled

Description:
Create a cluster with 2 zones.
Update a zone which does not have master node with master-disable:true zone capability. 
The nodes of that zone should not be allowed for master election.
Migrate master to the etcd node of updated zone capability. 
a. Using dctl cluster configure --master command. It should fail. 
b. Power off the master node or kill convoy. Master should not migrate to any of the nodes which are in updated zone.

1.Update the zone capability as master-disable:true in zone1 where master resides.
2.Kill convoy and armada of master node.
3.Master should not be scheduled on this node.
4.update the master-disable capability of the same zone i.e. zone1 as master-disable:false.
5. Now configure master to the etcd node of zone1 <dctl cluster configure --master>. Master should get configured on the this node successfully

Create cluster and 4 Mirrored Volumes of different sizes. Run Write FIO and compute the MD5Sum on volumes. Power-off Node-A. Swap drive-1 and drive-2 of Node-A and Power-on the system. Once the Node is Ready and volume attached, check the MD5Sum again on the volumes
ExpectedBehaviour: Slot number will change for the drive. Nodes will be UP and the MD5Sum should match

Description: Create cluster and 4 Volumes of different sizes. Run Write FIO and compute the MD5Sum on volumes. Power-off Node-A and Node-B. Swap drive-1 of Node-A with drive-1 of Node-B.
ExpectedBehaviour: Nodes should be in Not Ready state. Drives could be in Missing/Up/Foreign state depending on the order of drive discovery.

Description: Power-off Node-A and Node-B. Swap back drive-1 of Node-A with drive-1 of Node-B.
ExpectedBehaviour: Nodes should now be Ready state with all drives UP on all the nodes

Description: Create cluster and 4 Volumes of different sizes. Run Write FIO and compute the MD5Sum on volumes. Power-off Node-A and Node-B. Swap drive-1,2 of Node-A with drive-3,4 of Node-B.
ExpectedBehaviour: Nodes should be in Not Ready state. Drives could be in Missing/Up/Foreign state depending on the order of drive discovery.

Description: Power-off Node-A and Node-B. Swap back drive-1,2 of Node-A with drive-3,4 of Node-B.
ExpectedBehaviour: Nodes should now be Ready state with all drives UP on all the nodes

Description: Create cluster and 4 Volumes of different sizes. Run Write FIO and compute the MD5Sum on volumes. Power-off Node-A and Node-B.. Swap drive-1,2,3,4 of Node-A with drive-1,2,3,4 of Node-B.
ExpectedBehaviour: Nodes should be in Not Ready state. 8 Drives will be discovered. 4 will be Missing and 4 in Foreign state.

Description: Power-off Node-A and Node-B. Swap back drive-1,2,3,4 of Node-A with drive-1,2,3,4 of Node-B.
ExpectedBehaviour: Nodes should now be Ready state with all drives UP on all the nodes

Description: Create a 2-way mirrored volume and do Write FIO. Get the MD5Sum of the Volume. Destroy Cluster. Power-off the nodes and swap drive-1,2,3,4 on Node-A with drive-1,2,3,4 on Node-B. Power-on and Create the Cluster.
ExpectedBehaviour: Verify the Nodes are Ready, volumes are imported. Attach the volumes and verify the MD5Sum matches as before

Description: Have a 2 Node Cluster with Quorum Size as 2. Add 4 Volumes with 2-way plexes. Remove the non-quorum Node from the cluster using "dctl cluster remove" command. Move the drives from this Node to a new Node. Add the New Node to the Cluster using "dctl cluster add" command
ExpectedBehaviour: All the Volumes should end up showing with both the plexes. The Node-name should reflect the New-Node name for the plexes that on Drive-set that was moved to the New Node

Description: Have a 2 Node Cluster with Quorum Size as 2. Add 4 Volumes with 2-way plexes. Remove the non-quorum Node from the cluster using "dctl cluster remove" command. Run FIO on the remaining plexes. Move the drives from this Node to a new Node. Add the New Node to the Cluster using "dctl cluster add" command
ExpectedBehaviour: All the Volumes should end up showing with both the plexes. The Node-name should reflect the New-Node name for the plexes that on Drive-set that was moved to the New Node. Also, the plexes should resync and data should be consistent across plexes in a Volume

Description: Bringup 8 volumes on GA-1.0 Cluster and do Write FIO. Get the MD5Sum of the volumes. Destroy the Cluster. Re-Image the OS to 1.2.1 OS Image. Install the latest 1.2.1 RPM and create the Cluster
ExpectedBehaviour: Verify all the 8 volumes are imported and MD5Sum matches the as before. Run PODs on these volumes to verify the Volumes are usable

Description: Bringup 8 volumes on GA-1.0 Cluster and do Write FIO. Get the MD5Sum of the volumes. Destroy the Cluster. Re-Image the OS to 1.2.1 OS Image. Install the latest 1.2.1 RPM and create the Cluster
ExpectedBehaviour: Verify all the 8 volumes are imported and MD5Sum matches as before. Modify the volume to increase the number of plexes to 2 for 4 volumes and 3 for remaining 4 volumes. Verify that the new plexes resync once the Volumes are Attached

Description: Have a 3 Node Cluster with 2-way plexes running 1.2.0. Run FIO on the volumes and compute the MD5Sum. Cordon all the Nodes in the Cluster and upgrade the cluster to 1.2.1. Uncordon all the Nodes. All the volumes should show up with 2-way plexes. Modify the volume to plex-count 3
ExpectedBehaviour: The newly created plex should resync to the existing plex for all the volumes

Description:
Create cluster and mirrored volumes. Run fio job and calculate sha512sum.
Change the node id of one of the nodes. Reboot the node.

Create cluster and mirrored volumes. Run fio job and calculate sha512sum.
Swap node ids of two nodes. Reboot the node.
